text.text:
Besant Nagar Beach, commonly known as Elliot's Beach, is a prominent coastal destination in Chennai, India. This sandy expanse is a beloved spot for both locals and tourists, offering a unique blend of natural beauty and urban amenities.

One of the most appealing aspects of Besant Nagar Beach is its scenic charm. The beach is surrounded by lush greenery, with casuarina trees lining the shore, providing a picturesque backdrop for visitors. The golden sands, when kissed by the warm sun, create a serene atmosphere that invites you to relax and unwind.

The beach also has a vibrant atmosphere. It's a gathering place for Chennai's residents, and you'll often find people enjoying leisurely walks, engaging in yoga sessions, or simply relishing the sea breeze. Families come here for picnics, and it's a popular spot for children to build sandcastles and play in the gentle waves.

One can't overlook the fantastic culinary options nearby. The numerous food stalls and restaurants around the beach serve an array of delicious dishes, including mouthwatering street food and South Indian cuisine. Savoring local delicacies while gazing at the sea is a delightful experience.

Sunsets at Besant Nagar Beach are a true spectacle. As the sun descends into the Bay of Bengal, the sky is painted with brilliant hues, creating a mesmerizing view that draws photographers and romantics alike.

While Besant Nagar Beach is undoubtedly a great place to unwind, it's essential to mention that during peak seasons, it can get quite crowded, and littering can be an issue. The local authorities have made efforts to maintain cleanliness, but responsible tourism is crucial.

In summary, Besant Nagar Beach in Chennai is a captivating blend of natural beauty, cultural vibrancy, and culinary delights. It's a place where you can enjoy a relaxed day at the shore, savor local flavors, and witness breathtaking sunsets. While crowd management and cleanliness can be areas for improvement, the overall experience is one that leaves a lasting impression on visitors.

text.text:
Ashok Nagar is a residential locality situated at the southern part of Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India. It was established in 1964. At the heart of this colony, stands the Ashok Pillar. This four lion head stump, resembles the one erected by king Ashoka during the 3rd century BCE at Sanchi.To promote this suburban locality, the Tamil Nadu Housing Board constructed flats during the 1970s for middle-income group, covering an area of 7 sq km including the neighbourhood of K. K. Nagar.[1] The next major infrastructure was shopping complex constructed near Pillar in 1974. Banks, Ration shop, Grocery stores, urban development office were started functioning here. Followed by it was inauguration of Anna Community hall and sports club. In the early 1980s, Udhayam Theatre complex and ESI hospital emerged. Later more government schools and additional facilities were added.There is an intra-city connectivity from Ashok Nagar. Government city buses and share autos commutes to North, Mid and South Chennai.

There is a Metro station, opposite Udayam. It is the tallest metro station in Chennai and has been planned with 4 floors of shopping area. The area is one of the well-planned localities in Chennai, with broad roads and road-numbering system.The Udhayam Multiplex cinema with 4 screens is at Pillar junction. Also close by at Vadapalani are the Kamala, AVM Rajeswari, SSR Pangajam theatres Palazzo and Inox. Kasi theatre is at Ekattuthangal, about 5 min walk from Udhayam.

Sangamam, is a 10-day music & dance festival conducted across Chennai during the month of January. Ashok Nagar corporation park is one of the venue that hosts this festival.The corporation park is situated near pillar junction. This park has track for walking and a small play area for kids. It is well maintained with cleanliness and toilet facilities. Visitors should park their vehicles outside. Park timings are morning between 5 am and 9 am, evening between 4 pm and 9 pm. Chennai corporation's elected council gave the green signal to Metro Rail for taking over the 4,246 square metres of Corporation park in Ashok Nagar.

Kids play park at 12th Avenue is a compact play area for kids below 10. Park timings are morning between 5am and 9am, evening between 4 pm and 9 pm. This park is also called as 5E park.

The Manthope Colony Cricket ground located near Manthope Colony has many unofficial sports clubs. A Tennikoit and Badminton courts are there. Elders and Youths team up for match early mornings and weekends. Football is played in the evenings by many groups. This ground has flood lights which are lit up during evenings daily. Football is primarily played after 5 pmSri Chaitanya Techno curriculum

text.text:
Visited on 14th Oct 2023.

Arulmigu Vadapalani Murugan Temple, an eminent spiritual sanctuary in Chennai, is a testament to architectural and religious excellence. This revered temple, dedicated to Lord Murugan, presents a tranquil and sacred atmosphere for devotees and visitors alike.

Upon entering the temple premises, one is greeted by the imposing Rajagopuram, an architectural marvel adorned with intricate sculptures and vibrant colors. This serves as a gateway to a realm of spiritual serenity.

The temple's inner sanctum, housing the deity Lord Murugan, exudes an aura of divinity and offers a place for prayer and reflection. Devotees can participate in various rituals and ceremonies, enhancing their spiritual connection.

The temple complex is meticulously maintained, with cleanliness and order being paramount. It accommodates pilgrims of all backgrounds, fostering a sense of inclusivity and unity.

Arulmigu Vadapalani Murugan Temple is not only a spiritual hub but also an architectural gem, combining tradition and modernity seamlessly. Whether one seeks religious solace, cultural appreciation, or architectural wonder, this temple stands as a beacon of spirituality and heritage in Chennai.

text.text: Chennai's Marina Beach is a charming bay of Bengal length of golden sand that provides a tranquil haven in the middle of the busy metropolis. Both residents and visitors will find a gorgeous environment along its vast 13-kilometer coastline. Families taking leisurely strolls on the beach, sellers offering a wide variety of foods, and the distant silhouettes of fishing boats contributing to the picturesque beauty make the beach a bustling hub of activity. The magnificent Triumph of Labor sculpture and the well-known lighthouse at one end of the beach add to the area's cultural diversity. The strong sea currents may prevent swimming, and the beach's cleanliness isn't always consistent. Notwithstanding these difficulties, Marina Beach continues to be a popular choice for those looking to combine leisure with Chennai's vibrant energy. Even while the atmosphere captures the spirit of the region, efforts to keep the area clean and improve security measures could improve the overall experience for visitors. Marina Beach is a representation of Chennai's stunning coastline, inviting tourists to experience its distinct fusion of old and new.

text.text:
Marina Beach in Chennai, India, is a beloved and iconic destination known for its scenic beauty and vibrant atmosphere. Here's a review:

Marina Beach, stretching along the Bay of Bengal for approximately 13 kilometers, is one of the longest urban beaches in the world. Its golden sands, azure waters, and the backdrop of bustling Chennai create a unique charm that draws both locals and tourists.

The beach is a hub of activity throughout the day. In the early morning, it's a popular spot for joggers and yoga enthusiasts. As the day progresses, it comes alive with families, couples, and friends enjoying leisurely walks, picnics, and games.

One of the highlights of Marina Beach is the mesmerizing sunset. Watching the sun dip below the horizon, casting vibrant hues across the sky, is a magical experience that captures the hearts of all who visit.

Along the promenade, you'll find various food stalls selling delicious South Indian snacks, making it a great place to savor local flavors. The beach also hosts various events and cultural festivals, adding to its vibrancy.

While Marina Beach is a beautiful and lively destination, it's essential to exercise caution, especially regarding swimming, as the currents can be strong. Visitors should also be mindful of their belongings and stay hydrated, especially during hot days.

In summary, Marina Beach in Chennai offers a unique blend of natural beauty, cultural experiences, and a lively atmosphere. It's a must-visit destination for travelers looking to soak in the essence of Chennai's coastal life.

text.text:
Long queues Diminish Spiritual Experience

My recent visit to this temple was marred by the extensive queues that significantly impacted the overall experience. The prolonged wait times took away from the spiritual atmosphere the temple intended to foster.

Despite the temple's undoubtedly sacred ambiance, the overcrowded conditions and lengthy queues created an environment that felt rushed and chaotic. The management's inability to address the queue situation detracted from the intended tranquility of the visit.

While the temple itself may be well-maintained, the absence of an effective system to manage crowds had a noticeable impact on the overall satisfaction of the visit. For those seeking a more contemplative and serene temple experience, the prevalent long queues at this location may prove to be a hindrance.

text.text:
Anjaneyar Temple

The huge idol of Lord Hanuman, carved out of a single granite stone, without any breakpoint or streamline, is the main attraction of the Nanganallur Anjaneyar temple. The imposing idol stands 322 feet tall. It is black in hue and towers over the other shrines in the temple complex. In height, It ranks only second to the idol of Hanuman at Panchavati (near Puducherry) in terms of height.

The temple tower of the deity is also very high, almost 90 feet. The sanctum sanctorum is connected to the other shrines in the complex via corridors. There is a shrine for Sri Rama, Lakshmana, and Sita. Rama is always connected with Hanuman, and his presence is a given in any temple for Hanuman. Rama is depicted as the ruler and protector here; in the form, that Hanuman worships and respects. Rama carries a bow and is called Kothanda Rama. To acknowledge the fact that Hanuman was present in the Mahabharata as well, a shrine for Lord Krishna was also built. Krishna’s two consorts, Rukmini and Satyabhama, can also be seen alongside him. To save Arjuna's chariot from harm, during the Kurukshetra war, Hanuman graced the chariot’s flag, according to the Mahabharata.

There are two smaller shrines in the north-east part of the temple. One is for Lord Ganesha, and to its left, on another platform, is one for Naga or the snake god. Saint Raghavendra is also present, facing Krishna’s shrine. There is a large hall or mandapam for devotees to stand and pray to the deity. It can accommodate a lot of people.

text.text: Heads up - it's mostly a couples' park. Parking -- 2 wheeler (15) and 4 wheeler (20). Entry - 25 per head. There are several benches and CCTV cameras all over the place. The walking area is neat and all, but the ponds are mostly filled with algae. Nice sunshade under huge trees. Mostly, people are coming for the photoshoot. There's a children's play area too. Some families have even visited as a picnic spot bringing food. It would have been better if some security kept patrolling inside the park from time to time so that couples behave well.

text.text:
Recently visited this place expecting grandeur from Instagram, YouTube, and movies. However, it's smaller than anticipated with ongoing construction, making it messy. Despite this, features like the Open-Air Theater, Swale, Recreation Pond, Pergolas, and tall trees exist but require better maintenance.

Popular among young couples, photographers, and families, it caters to various activities. Entrance fees are ₹25 for adults, ₹10 for children, with additional parking charges (₹50 for cars, ₹15 for 2-wheelers).

Renovating water fountains and ponds could enhance its appeal and attract more visitors.

text.text:
So, stumbled upon Semmozhi Poonga on Instagram, and the reels made it seem like a must-visit. Last weekend, I decided to check it out with the family. First off, parking was a breeze – always a good sign.

Walking through this giant arch with a green slope and "Semmozhi Poonga" written on it was kind of cool. You could even climb it, giving a bit of adventure to the stroll. But, there's a 'but.' The entry fee was INR 25 for adults, which was fair, but when we arrived, maintenance work was in full swing, slightly messing with the vibes.

The place is like a little oasis in the middle of the city – lots of different plants, making it pretty chill. Now, here's the scoop!!!.
IT'S NOT EXACTLY A FAMILY HOTSPOT!!!!!!!!!!!. Everywhere you look, it's couples, each with their own umbrella love story. We visited right after rain, so I had my trusty umbrella, but I felt like I was on display with all the eyes checking us out.

To add to the mix, there's an Aavin booth at the end, but it was on a break due to park maintenance. Kind of a bummer. Long story short, bringing the family here wasn't my best call. Too much public display of affection around to roam and enjoy the park fully. So, for a quiet couples' escape, Semmozhi Poonga could be your spot, but maybe not the best family hangout.

editorialSummary.text: Large, tree-filled park with a variety of animals & greenery, plus a children's play area.

text.text:
I stumbled upon the Gunidy Snake Park by accident, as the adjacent Children's Park was closed for renovation. Surprisingly, it exceeded our expectations. The entry fees were reasonable, with kids at 10 rs, adults at 20 rs, and an additional 20 rs for carrying cameras or mobiles, while a separate camera incurred a 40 rs charge.

Inside, a variety of snakes, crocodiles, and turtles awaited. The park provided a satisfying experience for both kids and adults. Although some reptiles seemed motionless, leaving visitors questioning their authenticity, it added an intriguing touch. Turtles residing in a small pond were a delight for kids, despite the water needing cleaning.

The park offered small games, making it an enjoyable outing. However, the absence of restrooms is a drawback. The visit typically takes 1-2 hours, providing a quick yet entertaining experience. For reptile enthusiasts and those seeking educational value for kids, this place is a budget-friendly option.

As the Children's Park undergoes renovation, there's potential for the Snake Park to enhance its appeal by incorporating more reptiles and improving cleanliness. If these improvements are made, it could become a more engaging and educational destination for everyone. Overall, Gunidy Snack Park is a cost-effective and enjoyable option for a brief outing.

text.text:
Would request people to arrive early to reduce the rush..
I made it to the place at 9:30 AM on a Sunday morning and the place was quite empty.
The entrance fee for adults is 40rs and if you like Snakes, you will love the snake park.
There are various different varieties of Venomous and No Venomous ones ranging from Spectacled Cobra,Vipes,Kraits and Rock Python..

My favourite was the yellow Albino python.
There is a museum as well and there are specimens preserved in medical solutions..

There is a crocodile section as well having Saltwater crocodile, Gharial, Indian crocodile etc.

Worth a visit, and I enjoyed my time completely..

text.text:
Guindy National Park in Chennai is a serene sanctuary amidst the bustling cityscape, offering a unique natural escape. Spanning over 2.7 square kilometers, it's a haven for biodiversity enthusiasts and nature lovers. The park's diverse flora and fauna, including rare and endangered species, captivate visitors. Within its bounds, one can witness the graceful deer roaming freely, adding to the park's charm.
The park's landscape seamlessly integrates the city's urban fabric with nature, featuring a variety of trees, shrubs, and plants, providing a tranquil environment for leisurely walks and picnics. The Children's Park within Guindy National Park is an added delight for families, with its play areas and educational spots.
However, the park's maintenance and infrastructure could be improved to enhance the visitor experience. The signage and information about the wildlife and plant species could be more extensive for educational purposes.
Despite this, Guindy National Park remains a valuable gem, preserving Chennai's ecological balance while offering a respite from the city's daily chaos. It's a place that reminds us of the importance of conservation within an urban landscape, making it a worthwhile visit for nature enthusiasts and families seeking a serene retreat.

text.text:
I've been going to this temple since childhood. Such a wonderful divine place inside the temple alone. I guess since 2005/6 this place hasn't got changed a bit. After many years, I visited this temple on 26th Aug'23 , we reached the temple around 09.45pm on 22nd Aug'23 and decided to stay in the temple's accommodation itself. We were four(My nephews ,elder sister and me) carrying bed sheets and a few necessary things like a water bottle , Mosquito repellents , dress to change in the morning. The whole place was almost occupied, and we went to the other side of the place where only one ceiling fan was working. Somehow we managed until midnight, but then during 1.30am heavy rain started and water started to enter the accommodation place itself. And we had to rush where there was no water. Also, there is no shelter from accommodation to restrooms, most of the people were drenched in rain to use the toilets.

The toilets were very messy and disgusting, really fed up with the way the toilets were managed inside the temple premises.

And If you're planning to stay in the temple's accommodation , pls avoid it. d
Do stay in any nearby hotel and do visit only the temple even in the case of emergency do not enter the toilets inside the temple premises.

There are toilers named as "Free" outside the temple premise nearby "Puthu templ" behind the head tonsuring/ear piercing area. But the local women charge ten rupees from each person including kids. Here the toilets are somewhat better but still locks are broken no hot water facility.  Literally this area hasn't been changed even after 15 years, i visited last time in 2005/06 when I was in 5/6th grade in school.

Most importantly the hotels were so good earlier and I couldn't find any of those good hotels for breakfast outside the temple area. I had breakfast at the nearby bus depot it was terrible.

Need a lot of improvement to develop basic amenities inside the temple accommodation place.

editorialSummary.text: Historic high court of Madras, built in 1892, featuring monumental Indo-Saracenic architecture.

text.text:
The High Court of Judicature at Madras, one of the three High Courts in India established at the Presidency Towns by Letters Patent granted by Her Majesty Queen Victoria, bearing date 26th June 1862    is the highest Court in the State of Tamil Nadu, exercising Original Jurisdiction over the City of Madras and Appellate Jurisdiction over the entire State as well as extra-ordinary Original Jurisdiction, Civil and Criminal, under the Letters Patent and Special Original Jurisdiction for the issue of writs under the Constitution of India.

The Hon`ble The Chief Justice is the Head of the Judiciary with powers of administration of the High Court and of the Administration of Justice throughout the State. The Hon’ble Chief Justice is in charge of the general policy adopted in the Administration of Justice.

text.text:
The High Court of Judicature at Madras, one of the three High Courts in India established at the Presidency Towns by Letters Patent granted by Her Majesty Queen Victoria, bearing date 26th June 1862    (   The Charters of the High Court of Judicature at Madras (104 MB) ￼  ), is the highest Court in the State of Tamil Nadu, exercising Original Jurisdiction over the City of Madras and Appellate Jurisdiction over the entire State as well as extra-ordinary Original Jurisdiction, Civil and Criminal, under the Letters Patent and Special Original Jurisdiction for the issue of writs under the Constitution of India.

The Hon`ble The Chief Justice is the Head of the Judiciary with powers of administration of the High Court and of the Administration of Justice throughout the State. The Hon’ble Chief Justice is in charge of the general policy adopted in the Administration of Justice. The administration of Justice in the Civil and Criminal Courts in the districts constituted under the Civil Courts Act and the Code of Criminal Procedure respectively is carried on by the following categories of Judicial officers.

Civil
a) District Judges
b) Senior Civil Judges
c) Civil Judges

Criminal
a) Sessions Judges
b) Chief Judicial Magistrates
c) Assistant Sessions Judges
d) Judicial Magistrates

text.text:
✨The High Court complex is located in the southern end of George town.
The building was constructed after relocating temples on the land. The building now used exclusively by the High Court was built to also house the Courts of Small Causes and the City Civil Court.

✨Architecture- 🏛️- The High Court building is an example of Indo- Saracenic architecture.
You will find tall minarets. This building is the greatest Heritage for the people in Chennai.
Its tree-lined squares and red-brick buildings have witnessed many important moments in Indian legal history.

✨History - Construction began in October 1888 and was completed in 1892 following the design prepared by J. W. Brassington and later under the guidance of architect Henry Irwin, who completed it with the assistance of J. H. Stephens.

editorialSummary.text: Iconic 12-story tower with a spiraling ramp overlooking a surrounding park, fountain & sport courts.

text.text: Anna Tower in Anna Nagar is a must-visit gem. Nestled at a prime location with entrances near Ayyappan temple and 3rd main road, it stands tall as the highest park tower in Chennai—12 stories, 135 feet of architectural marvel. The spiraling ramp and captivating fountains, illuminated at night, add to its allure.Managed by the diligent Chennai Corporation, the park welcomes visitors from 7AM to 10AM and 3PM to 6PM. Ascend to the top for breathtaking city views. Discover a haven for children with play areas, lakes, an amphitheater, and a vibrant skating rink. The weekends come alive with kids engaging in various activities, including delightful skating sessions.Anticipate weekend crowds and limited 4-wheel parking; however, 2-wheel parking options are conveniently available. Authorities are encouraged to enhance parking arrangements. Indulge in the diverse culinary offerings from nearby fast-food options, completing a delightful visit to this enchanting park.

text.text:
Anna Tower Park presents a dual experience for visitors. On one hand, it offers a serene atmosphere for relaxation and exercise, with plenty of well-maintained benches providing comfortable resting spots. However, during my visit, I was disappointed to find that the water fountains were not working, and the ponds were empty, which detracted from the overall appeal.

The park's tower, on the other hand, is a standout feature, providing an excellent viewpoint with stunning views of Chennai from the top. It's an opportunity to appreciate the city's beauty from a different perspective. Regrettably, the tower's walls have been vandalized by some visitors with indecent and vulgar phrases. It's crucial that everyone respects the artistic value of the structure and refrains from such behavior, ensuring that this remarkable viewpoint remains a cherished attraction for all.
